dialogs.original: No, faith, Ill not stay a jot longer.
dialogs.translated: No, really, I won't stay a moment longer.

dialogs.original: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.
dialogs.translated: What's your reason for leaving, my bitter friend?

dialogs.original: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.
dialogs.translated: Yes, you must tell us your reason, Sir Andrew.

dialogs.original: Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Counts servingman than ever she bestowed upon me. I sawt i'theorchard.
dialogs.translated: Well, I saw your niece Olivia treating the Duke's messenger better than she has ever treated me. I saw it in the garden.

dialogs.original: Did she see thee the while, old boy? Tell me that.
dialogs.translated: Did she see you at the time though, old boy? Tell me that.

dialogs.original: As plain as I see you now.
dialogs.translated: Yes, she saw me as plainly as I see you now.

dialogs.original: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.
dialogs.translated: Then that was proof that she loves you.

dialogs.original: 'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?
dialogs.translated: What, are trying to make a fool of me?

dialogs.original: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.
dialogs.translated: I'll prove it to be true, sir, with judgment and logic.

dialogs.original: And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.
dialogs.translated: And judgment and logic have been wise jury members since the time of Noah's ark.

dialogs.original: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.   You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.   This was looked for at your hand, and this was balked.   The double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash off, and you are now sailed into the north of my ladys opinion, where you will hang like an icicle on a Dutchmans beard,   unless you do redeem it by some laudable attempt either of valor or policy.
dialogs.translated: She treated the youth so well while you were watching to exasperate and anger you, to wake up your meekly sleeping boldness, to fire up your passions. You should have approached her that minute, whipped out some excellent jokes you invented right there on the spot, and humiliated the youth into silence. That was the opening she gave you, but you missed it. This was a golden opportunity for you, but you let it slip away, and now you've sailed out of the warmth of my lady's good opinion. You'll stay there like an icicle in a sailor's beard unless you can redeem yourself to her through some noble act of bravery or politics.

dialogs.original: An t be any way, it must be with valor, for policy I hate. I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.
dialogs.translated: If I have to do something, it must be something brave, for I hate politics. I'd rather be a heretic than a politician.

dialogs.original: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor. Challenge me the counts youth to fight with him.   Hurt him in eleven places. My niece shall take note of it,   and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in mans commendation with woman than report of valor.
dialogs.translated: Well then, improve your fortunes through your bravery. Challenge the duke's young servant to a fight. Hurt him in eleven places. My niece will notice this, and let me assure you, no matchmaker in the world can win you a woman's love like a reputation for bravery can.

dialogs.original: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.
dialogs.translated: This is the only way, Sir Andrew.

dialogs.original: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?
dialogs.translated: Will either of you deliver the message of my challenge to him?

dialogs.original: Go, write it in a martial hand. Be curst and brief. Itis no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention.   Taunt him with the license of ink.   If thou thou-est him some thrice, it shall not be amiss; and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of paper, althoughthe sheet were big enough for the bed of Ware in England, set 'em down.   Go, about it. Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou write with a goose-pen, no matter. About it.
dialogs.translated: Go and write it down, in fierce handwriting. Be rude and brief. It doesn't need to be witty, as long as it's eloquent and original. Taunt him with all the possibilities of writing. Refer to him familiarly three times at least, which will insult his pride as a nobleman. As many lies as you can fit on a piece of papereven if the paper's as big as a royal bedwrite 'em all down. Go, get started now. Even if you're using an ordinary pen, you can still fill it with bitter, venomous ink. Now go ahead.

dialogs.original: Where shall I find you?
dialogs.translated: Where will I find you when I'm done?

dialogs.original: Well call thee at the cubiculo. Go.
dialogs.translated: We'll meet you in the little room. Now go.

dialogs.original: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.
dialogs.translated: This knight is a beloved puppet to you, Sir Toby.

dialogs.original: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong,or so.
dialogs.translated: And I've been a beloved expense to him, as he's spent two thousand or so of his ducats on me.

dialogs.original: We shall have a rare letter from him: but youll not deliver t?
dialogs.translated: His letter's sure to be a work of art. But you won't deliver it, will you?

dialogs.original: Never trust me, then. And by all means stir on the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together.   For Andrew, if he were opened and you find so much blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, Ill eat the rest of the anatomy.
dialogs.translated: Never trust me again if I don't. And by all means encourage the youth to answer the knight's challenge. An oxcart couldn't haul them close enough together to fight. As for Andrew, if you dissected him and found enough red blood in his liver for even a flea to notice, I'd eat the rest of his body. He's a coward through and through.

dialogs.original: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.
dialogs.translated: And his opponent, the youth, doesn't seem to have much aggression in his face either.

dialogs.original: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.
dialogs.translated: Look, here comes the smallest bird of all.

dialogs.original: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me.   Yond gull Malvolio is turned heathen, a very renegado. For there is no Christian thatmeans to be saved by believing rightly can ever believesuch impossible passages of grossness.   Hes in yellow stockings.
dialogs.translated: If you want to have a laughing fit, and really laugh until you split your sides, then follow me. That gullible Malvolio must have renounced Christianity, for no Christian who intends to go to heaven by his faith could ever believe the absurd, exaggerated things like we put in that letter. He's wearing yellow stockings.

dialogs.original: And cross-gartered?
dialogs.translated: With crossed laces?

dialogs.original: Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church.   I have dogged him, like his murderer. He does obey every point of the letter that I dropped to betray him.   He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies.    You have not seen such a thing as tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things at him.   I know my lady will strike him. If she do, hell smile and take t for a great favor.
dialogs.translated: Yes, and they look awfullike an unfashionable village schoolteacher. I've been stalking him like a murderer, and he's followed every instruction I gave in that letter I dropped. He smiles so much that his face has more lines in it than a map of the Indies. You've never seen anything like this. I can hardly keep from throwing things at him. I know my lady will get so annoyed she'll hit him eventually, and when she does, he'll just smile and imagine that she's flattering him.

dialogs.original: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
dialogs.translated: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
